awd_titl_txt: The Cognitive Basis of Linguistic Illusions
awd_abstract_narration:
Our ability to use and understand language in everyday conversation is a feat that seems to be accomplished both rapidly and effortlessly. Just as the impression that our visual interpretation of the world around us is robust and complete, our impression of language is similarly rich. Behind the perceived ease of language understanding is a complex set of neuro-cognitive mechanisms that must work in tandem to give us a rich linguistic experience. However, these systems are not always foolproof and can be misled, arriving at unintended interpretations or the perception of ill-formed sentences as if they were well-formed. These errors trigger what are known as "linguistic illusions", and just as visual illusions have transformed our understanding of how our visual system interprets the world around us, the systematic study of linguistic illusions can transform our understanding of how we interpret language. Importantly, by studying the conditions under which we do and do not fall for linguistic illusions, we can improve language technologies, provide better language learning instruction, and aid in assessments of cognitive impairments.  

The goal of this project is to better understand the scope and cause of linguistic illusions. Current language processing models assume that illusions are the product of two distinct cognitive systems: one system for fast, efficient communication (the 'parser'), and another, slower system that classifies grammaticality (the 'grammar'). A competing account claims that illusions reflect a single grammar system embedded in a noisy cognitive architecture that creates the opportunity for errors. The current project addresses this debate by extending research to a broader set of linguistic phenomena using behavioral and computational methods to better understand the exact conditions that trigger illusions. This project will inform our understanding of (i) the cognitive architecture of language, (ii) the mental mechanisms for encoding, accessing, and manipulating sentence structures, and (iii) the role of the grammar in sentence processing. The project will have a direct impact on the broader scientific community, the undergraduate researchers funded through project, and the general public. Specifically, the project will expand the pool of participants that are typically included in psycholinguistic studies to non-college students, leading to a more comprehensive study of linguistic abilities across populations, and will bridge research and education by providing meaningful research experiences to undergraduate researchers, including under-represented minorities, through undergraduate training boot camps, research assistantships, and outreach activities at K-12 schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the phenomenon of “linguistic illusions” in sentence processing—situations where language users misperceive grammatically correct sentences as incorrect or interpret ungrammatical sentences as acceptable. These illusions offer a unique window into the cognitive architecture underlying human language comprehension. By identifying when and why such misperceptions occur, this research deepens our understanding of how people process language in real time and how memory, attention, and predictive mechanisms shape interpretation.

Over the course of the project, a series of behavioral and computational experiments were conducted to investigate multiple types of linguistic illusions, including agreement attraction and illusory licensing of negative polarity items (NPIs). The findings reveal that many of these illusions stem from interference effects in memory retrieval and structural prediction during sentence processing. These results not only clarify the mechanisms responsible for (mis)interpretation but also extend theoretical models of language comprehension and contribute to broader theories of cognition.

The intellectual contributions of the project have been disseminated widely through scholarly publications, including a research monograph (Linguistic Illusions: A Case Study on Agreement Attraction, Cambridge University Press) and various publications in top journals in the field, such as Journal of Memory and Language and Cognitive Science. Findings were also presented at major academic conferences, including the Human Sentence Processing conference and invited talks at several domestic and international institutions.

In addition to its scientific contributions, the project has made a meaningful impact on education and public engagement. Research findings have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate curricula at The Ohio State University, enriching course content and providing students with exposure to current methodologies and research questions in psycholinguistics. The project also supported student training in experimental design, data analysis, and computational modeling—critical skills for future researchers in the language sciences.

A key broader impact of the project has been its outreach work with local high schools in the Columbus, Ohio area. These events introduced high school students to the science of language and cognitive psychology through engaging, interactive sessions. The outreach not only promoted STEM interest among students from diverse backgrounds but also helped demystify the research process and highlight the relevance of language science in everyday communication.

Importantly, all data generated through the project have been made publicly available, providing an open-access resource for the broader research community. These datasets contribute to scientific transparency and reproducibility and offer valuable material for future research in linguistics, cognitive science, computational modeling, and education.

In sum, this project has advanced theoretical and empirical understanding in the field of psycholinguistics, contributed new tools and insights to interdisciplinary research, supported educational innovation, and engaged the public in meaningful ways. It stands as a successful example of how federally funded research can simultaneously expand scientific knowledge and promote broader societal benefit.
